string-array.item: Know Your Limits: Understand your own tolerance level and drink responsibly. It\'s important to know when to stop and never drink to excess.
Stay Hydrated: Alternate between alcoholic drinks and water to stay hydrated. Alcohol can dehydrate you, so it\'s crucial to maintain a good balance.
Choose Quality Ingredients: Opt for high-quality spirits and fresh ingredients when making or ordering cocktails. Quality ingredients can enhance the taste and reduce the chances of a hangover.
Pace Yourself: Enjoy your drink slowly. Sip and savor the flavors rather than rushing through it. This also gives your body time to process the alcohol.
Eat Before Drinking: Having a meal before drinking can slow down the absorption of alcohol into your bloodstream, reducing its effects.
Be Mindful of Mixing: Avoid mixing different types of alcohol in one sitting. Stick to one type of liquor or cocktail to prevent an upset stomach or undesirable effects.
Know What You\'re Drinking: Familiarize yourself with the ingredients and alcohol content of the cocktails you\'re consuming. Some cocktails may be stronger than others.

Designated Driver or Alternative Transportation: If you\'re planning to drink, ensure you have a designated driver or arrange for alternative transportation like a taxi or rideshare service to get home safely.
Watch for Allergies and Sensitivities: Be mindful of any allergies or sensitivities you may have to certain ingredients in cocktails. Always ask the bartender about ingredients if you\'re unsure.
Respect Others\' Choices: Not everyone drinks alcohol. Respect others\' choices if they choose not to consume alcoholic beverages and never pressure anyone to drink.
Avoid Drinking on an Empty Stomach: Drinking on an empty stomach can lead to quicker intoxication. Have a snack or meal before drinking to help slow the absorption of alcohol.
Listen to Your Body: Pay attention to how you\'re feeling. If you start to feel unwell or too intoxicated, stop drinking and seek assistance if needed.
